titleInfo.title: Convention, Madness, and the Unruly Heroine in Two American Operas
titleInfo.subTitle: Libby Larsen's Clair De Lune and Daron Hagen's Amelia

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation examines the portrayals of unconventional and "unruly" female characters in two American operas of the late-twentieth and early-twenty-first centuries, Clair de Lune (1984) by Libby Larsen and Patricia Hampl, and Amelia (2010) by Daron Hagen, Gardner McFall, and Stephen Wadsworth. I explore how these recent works variously reflect, embody, and undermine the art form's historically problematic depictions of such women. Although one of opera's central pillars is its adoration and exhibition of the feats achievable by the female voice, female opera characters, particularly those who threaten the societal conventions depicted onstage, are consistently manipulated, sabotaged, and often violently removed before the final curtain falls. As my case studies demonstrate, the figure of the transgressive operatic heroine continues to captivate composers and librettists as they choose to center such a figure in their works. Clair de Lune and Amelia are each set in the twentieth-century United States and comprise largely historical and realistic plots. Both operas also feature an aviatrix as a major character. The presence of an aviatrix allows me to examine an atypical operatic character and an operatic portrayal of an exceptional kind of woman, as well as differing representations of flight in each work. These operas celebrate women who reject external attempts to control them; more importantly, perhaps, the women emerge from their respective plots alive and in some state of self-possession. Although each opera depicts a heroine who transgresses societal pressures, the ways in which the two operas treat her and the resolution she reaches by the final curtain articulate differing perspectives on the genre's historical treatment of women. These two works demonstrate an art form continuing to wrestle with its legacy, with differing degrees of success. Clair de Lune and Amelia reflect numerous ways in which opera's past casts a long shadow. Each opera reckons with inherited conventions, variously commenting upon, critiquing, or embracing them as a model. Each enacts self-conscious references to opera's history through quotation, satire, and structure. I focus particularly on how each opera engages with the operatic convention of the mad scene, and I explore how these portrayals are tied to a complex medico-cultural history of female hysteria. Within these sites of inquiry, I question the ways in which contemporary opera is still beholden to legacies of the past, and I explicate how these works speak to opera's potential and future as a vibrant and empowering art form that variously challenges or embraces the traditional roles of its women.
